instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have a 2019 MacBook Pro board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with very minor liquid damage (area between J5110 and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>). <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> is stuck at 5V. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5 Ohms to ground. I injected 3.3V and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> got hot, so I removed it. The short to ground remained and further current injection did not cause any immediate heating I could find.

Where do I go from here, without any temperature changes to guide me?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Still 5 ohm to ground there?
Is that ohm scale, or diode mode reading?

Not being pure short, is not easy to heat something; the injected current is low.
You may go until 4V, no more.
A thermal camera can help you; as it can detect small temp deviations.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I went up to 4V injection and found <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> warm. Removed <CHIP>U8200</CHIP> and now the short to ground is 26 Ohms using resistance mode and 0.024 using diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Still bad; something more damaged there.
Diode mode reading should be approx 300-350...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: With applied 4V I can see several components getting hot, but I assume those are simply components in the network warming up from 7A flowing through <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, really. I know it breaks Ohm's law... maybe it's a sign to give up on this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This is only possible if some chip enters into thermal avalanche; but should be easy to detect it then.
If you mean that just set amp limit to 7A, doesn't mean the board sinks that current.
Set always amp limit to max; board will take the corresponding current to injected voltage and ohm value to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: My current is set to max (10A). The power supply says it is putting out 6-7 A at 4 V. I measure a negative voltage on my multimeter during current injection... does that also indicate thermal avalanche?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That means 24-27W, something should go really hot.
At least a thermal cam must show something very clear.
You should get 4V indicated by the PSU.
If not,you are doing something wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks for that comment, I indeed had a wiring issue with my PSU. Fixed now. I now do get 3.7 V when I apply 4 V from the PSU, with a current draw of 0.8 A. Resuming troubleshooting...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That is really low, approx 3W.
A thermal camera is required, and not sure if really helps.
Don't forget to remove CPU heatsink first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I found a 1cm x 1cm area of the board underside that slowly but consistently gets warm after several minutes. Unfortunately I think it corresponds to the footprint of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (PMIC) on the board topside, under the heat shield.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Need to remove the shield and confirm it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I removed the shield and confirmed that <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is getting hot. This PMU is not commercially available as a spare part, correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You need scrap board to get it...
